etymologies: Old English sincan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zinken and German sinken

notes.text: Historically, the past tense of sink has been both sank and sunk (the boat sank; the boat sunk), and the past participle has been both sunk and sunken (the boat had already sunk; the boat had already sunken). In modern English, the past is generally sank and the past participle is sunk, with the form sunken now surviving only as an adjective, as in a sunken garden or sunken cheeks

definitions: go down below the surface of something, especially of a liquid; become submerged

examples.text: he saw the coffin sink below the surface of the waves

shortDefinitions: go down below surface of something

definitions: (of a ship) go to the bottom of the sea or some other body of water because of damage or a collision

examples.text: the trawler sank with the loss of all six crew members

shortDefinitions: (of ship) go to bottom of sea or some other body of water because of damage

definitions: cause (a ship) to go to the bottom of the sea or other body of water

examples.text: a freak wave sank their boat near the shore

shortDefinitions: cause ship to sink

definitions: disappear and not be seen or heard of again

examples.text: the film sank virtually without trace

shortDefinitions: fail and not be seen or heard of again

definitions: cause to fail

examples.text: she apparently wishes to sink the company

shortDefinitions: cause to fail

definitions: conceal, keep in the background, or ignore

examples.text: they agreed to sink their differences

shortDefinitions: conceal, keep in background, or ignore

definitions: descend; drop

examples.text: you can relax on the veranda as the sun sinks
Sam felt the ground sinking beneath his feet

shortDefinitions: descend from higher to lower position

definitions: (of a person) lower oneself or drop gently

examples.text: she sank back onto her pillow

shortDefinitions: lower oneself or drop down gently

definitions: gradually penetrate into the surface of something

examples.text: her feet sank into the thick pile of the carpet

shortDefinitions: gradually penetrate into surface of something

definitions: gradually decrease or decline in value, amount, quality, or intensity

examples.text: their output sank to a third of the prewar figure
the reputation of the mayor sank to a very low level

shortDefinitions: gradually decrease or decline in value, amount or intensity

definitions: approach death

examples.text: the doctor concluded that Sanders was sinking fast

shortDefinitions: approach death

definitions: insert beneath a surface by digging or hollowing out

examples.text: rails attached with screws sunk below the surface of the wood

shortDefinitions: insert beneath surface

definitions: insert into something

examples.text: Kelly stood watching, her hands sunk deep into her pockets

shortDefinitions: push or thrust object into something

definitions: excavate (a well) or bore (a shaft) more or less vertically downward

examples.text: they planned to sink a gold mine in Oklahoma

shortDefinitions: excavate well or bore shaft vertically downwards

definitions: hit (a ball) into a hole in golf or billiards

examples.text: he sank the black into the green pocket to secure victory

shortDefinitions: hit ball into hole in golf or snooker

definitions: (in golf) hit the ball into the hole with (a putt or other shot)

examples.text: he sank a four-foot birdie putt at the fifth hole

shortDefinitions: (in golf) hit ball into hole with

definitions: a fixed basin with a water supply and a drain

examples.text: I stood at the kitchen sink
a sink unit with cupboard and drawers under

shortDefinitions: fixed basin with water supply and outflow pipe

definitions: a pool or marsh in which a river's water disappears by evaporation or percolation.
shortDefinitions: pool or marsh in which river's water disappears by evaporation or percolation

definitions: a body or process which acts to absorb or remove energy or a particular component from a system

examples.text: a heat sink
the oceans can act as a sink for CO₂

shortDefinitions: body or process which acts to absorb or remove energy or particular component from system

definitions: a place of vice or corruption

examples.text: a sink of unnatural vice, pride, and luxury

shortDefinitions: place of vice or corruption
